title: English (1709) First English American Bible (portions)
description:
The first English American Bible, translated by Experience Mayhew in 1709, is an adaptation of John Eliot's earlier translation. According to Trumbull, "every verse underwent revision and scarcely one remains without some alteration."

The Eliot Indian Bible, officially titled "Mamusse Wunneetupanatamwe Up-Biblum God" and commonly known as the Algonquian Bible, was the first translation of the Christian Bible into an indigenous American language and the first Bible published in British North America. John Eliot, an English Puritan missionary, translated the Geneva Bible into the Massachusett language. This groundbreaking work was first printed in Cambridge, Massachusetts, initially with just the New Testament in 1661. A complete edition featuring all 66 books of the Old and New Testaments followed in 1663.

The 1663 edition's cover page, inscribed with "Mamusse Wunneetupanatamwe Up Biblum God," translates to "The Whole Holy His-Bible God, both Old Testament and also New Testament. This turned by the servant of Christ, who is called John Eliot." The production and printing of Eliot's translation were supported by the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in New England, headed by the renowned scientist Robert Boyle.
